questions.question_text: How does a Snowflake user extract the URL of a directory table on an external stage for further transformation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The GET_STAGE_LOCATION function returns the location of a stage, including the URL of the directory table. The syntax for the GET_STAGE_LOCATION function.
SELECT GET_STAGE_LOCATION('my_stage')

questions.question_text:
A Snowflake user needs to share unstructured data from an internal stage to a reporting tool that does not have Snowflake access.

Which file function should be used?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/unstructured-intro
Search in page for
Types of URLs Available to Access Files

Pre-signed URL
Used to download or access files without authenticating into Snowflake or passing an authorization token. Pre-signed URLs are open; any user or application can directly access or download the files. Ideal for business intelligence applications or reporting tools that need to display the unstructured file contents.

Selected Answer: C
C correct answer. Pre-signed URLs are open; any user or application can directly access or download the files

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

questions.question_text: The use of which Snowflake table type will reduce costs when working with ETL workflows?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C since temporary tables are only available for the duration of a session, and they are not stored in Snowflake's permanent storage. This means that they do not incur any storage costs.

Selected Answer: D
Temporary tables exist only for the duration of the session and do not incur long-term storage costs. However, they are not accessible across sessions, which can limit their use in complex ETL workflows.

Transient tables strike the right balance between cost-effectiveness and functionality for ETL processes.
it should be D. temporary tables will get deleted as session terminates.

Selected Answer: C
A view can only be shared if it is created as a secure view or marked secure using the ALTER VIEW view_name SET_SECURE statement.

comments.content:
Data sharing in Snowflake is read-only, meaning that all database objects shared between accounts cannot be modified or deleted, including adding or modifying table data 1.
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/data-sharing-intro

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
the right is A DML are supported in share

choices.B: Data shares work by copying data to consumer accounts.
choices.A: Data shares support full DML operations.
choices.C: Data shares utilize secure views for sharing view objects.
choices.D: Data shares are cloud agnostic and can cross regions by default.

questions.question_text: What is one of the characteristics of data shares?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The timeout period begins upon a successful authentication to Snowflake. If a session policy is not set, Snowflake uses a default value of 240 minutes (i.e. 4 hours). The minimum configurable idle timeout value for a session policy is 5 minutes. When the session expires, the user must authenticate to Snowflake again.

questions.question_text: What is the MINIMUM configurable idle timeout value for a session policy in Snowflake?
